newsitem.title: GUATEMALA: Group demands justice for murdered journalists.
newsitem.headline: Group demands justice for murdered journalists.

text.p: When journalists die violently in Latin America no one seems to care. Corruption and ineptitude block official investigations. The killers and those who gave the orders to kill remain free.
Those were among the conclusions on Friday of the annual conference of the Interamerican Press Association (IAPA) following three days of meetings focusing on the unpunished murders of journalists.
"There is a lack of consistent public outrage. ... We have found that impunity is the rule and not the exception," IAPA Vice President Oliver Clarke said in a speech at the closing of the conference.
At least 169 journalists were murdered in the Americas in the last seven years, and almost none of the cases have been solved, IAPA said.
Clarke, of the Jamaican newspaper The Daily Gleamer, said violence against journalists had not stopped and may even have increased in countries enjoying new democratic governments.
Publishers from across the hemisphere called on governments to open up closed files and get to the bottom of these deaths.
"We urge that governments complete full investigations of crimes against journalists," said a document of recommendations drafted at the conference.
Participants in the conference heard wrenching testimony from family members of six journalists killed in Guatemala, Mexico and Colombia.

Marta de Carpio said her husband, Guatemalan politician and newspaperman Jorge Carpio, died in her arms after 30 armed men ambushed them on a country road in July 1993. She said she knows it was a hit because she still remembers one of them yelling, "kill Jorge, kill Carpio."
But the "police kept insisting it was a common crime," de Carpio said bitterly.
Eight different judges have passed the case around like a hot potato, files have been lost and false evidence presented and then destroyed, de Carpio said.
Former Nicaraguan President Violeta Chamorro, widow of a slain newspaper editor, was visibly moved as she heard de Carpio's story.

Chamorro was part of a commission of notables, including politicians, judges, media chief and other influential Latin Americans, that listened to the testimony and helped draft recommendations at the conclusion of the conference.

Witnesses also gave testimony on the cases of five other slain journalists: Colombians Guillermo Cano Isaza, murdered in 1986, and Carlos Lajud Catalan, killed in 1993; Guatemalan Irma Flaquer Azurdia, who disappeared in 1980; and Mexicans Hector Felix Miranda, killed in 1988, and Victor Manuel Oropeza, murdered in 1991.
